title: Paraesophageal Hernia
diagnosis_topic: Herniation of stomach alongside the esophagus through the hiatus
setup_script: A 72-year-old woman complains of postprandial chest discomfort, early satiety and occasional dyspnea. She has a history of iron deficiency anemia.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 130/75 mmHg, HR 85 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 36.9 C.
Retrocardiac air-fluid level suggestive of intrathoracic stomach.
Large paraesophageal hernia with the gastric fundus herniated into thorax; minimal gastroesophageal junction displacement.
Cameron ulcers present and mild esophagitis; biopsies taken.
Iron deficiency anemia with ferritin 10 ng/mL; stool occult blood positive.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses indications for surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: Symptomatic paraesophageal hernia with anemia and potential for volvulus; recommend surgical repair.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident plans laparoscopic reduction, hernia sac excision, crural repair and fundoplication
dynamic_flow.reply: Describes steps including mesh reinforcement if large defect.
Risk of gastric volvulus, strangulation, bleeding and aspiration pneumonia increases.
Confirms normal esophageal motility; guides fundoplication choice (Nissen vs. Toupet).
Gradual diet progression, small frequent meals, monitor for dysphagia or gas bloat syndrome.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If patient is asymptomatic with small hernia
dynamic_flow.reply: Watchful waiting may be reasonable; counsel on warning signs.
Importance of iron supplementation until surgery and follow-up to monitor for recurrence.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of paraesophageal hernia using imaging and endoscopy
Recognition of indications for surgical repair including symptoms and complications
Components of laparoscopic hernia repair and fundoplication
Preoperative assessment of esophageal motility and postoperative dietary modifications
Risks of watchful waiting versus surgery and patient counseling
